items.description: Analyze repository structure and set up project scaffold
items.acceptance_criteria: Create a project scaffold with directories src/, tests/, figures/, results/. Write a MODULE_MAP.md listing each planned module (vector math, body, force computation, integrators, simulation loop, visualization) with a one-sentence purpose for each.

items.description: Formalize the research problem: minimal N-body gravity simulation
items.acceptance_criteria: Write PROBLEM.md defining: (1) the gravitational N-body problem with Newton's law F = G*m1*m2/r^2, (2) scope limited to 2D point masses, (3) key challenges (energy drift, close encounters, computational cost), (4) success metric: total energy conservation |dE/E0| < 1e-4 over 1000 orbital periods for a two-body Kepler orbit.

items.description: Conduct literature review on N-body simulation methods via web search
items.acceptance_criteria: Search the web for papers and resources on: symplectic integrators, Verlet/leapfrog methods, Barnes-Hut algorithm, adaptive time-stepping for gravitational N-body, and softening parameters. Produce LITERATURE_REVIEW.md summarizing at least 10 key findings with inline citations. Topics must include Aarseth (2003), Dehnen & Read (2011), Barnes & Hut (1986), Wisdom & Holman (1991), and at least 6 additional sources.

items.description: Create and populate sources.bib with BibTeX entries for all consulted sources
items.acceptance_criteria: sources.bib exists in repo root with valid BibTeX entries for at least 10 relevant papers. Each entry must have author, title, year, and journal/booktitle fields. Entries must include foundational works on leapfrog integration, Barnes-Hut tree codes, and symplectic methods.

items.description: Survey existing open-source gravity simulators and N-body codes
items.acceptance_criteria: Search GitHub and the web for at least 5 existing minimal gravity/N-body simulators (e.g., rebound, GADGET, nbodykit, simple Python demos). Document each in CODE_SURVEY.md with: language, integration method used, feature set, and lines of code. Identify design patterns to adopt for our minimal implementation.

items.description: Implement 2D vector math module
items.acceptance_criteria: src/vector.py exists with a Vec2 class supporting addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, dot product, magnitude, and unit vector. At least 8 unit tests in tests/test_vector.py, all passing.

items.description: Implement Body class and gravitational force computation
items.acceptance_criteria: src/body.py defines a Body class (mass, position, velocity). src/force.py computes pairwise gravitational acceleration with a configurable softening parameter epsilon. At least 5 unit tests verifying force magnitude matches analytic F=Gm1m2/r^2 for known configurations.

items.description: Implement Euler and leapfrog (Stormer-Verlet) integrators
items.acceptance_criteria: src/integrators.py contains both an Euler integrator and a leapfrog (kick-drift-kick) integrator, each accepting a list of bodies and a timestep dt. At least 6 unit tests confirming both integrators produce correct single-step updates for a known two-body configuration.

items.description: Implement simulation loop with energy tracking
items.acceptance_criteria: src/simulation.py provides a Simulation class that runs N steps of a chosen integrator, computing and recording total energy (kinetic + potential) at each step. Energy computation verified against analytic value for a circular two-body orbit to within 1e-6 relative error.

items.description: Establish baseline benchmarks: Euler vs leapfrog on Kepler orbit
items.acceptance_criteria: Run both integrators on a two-body Kepler orbit (e=0 and e=0.5) for 100 orbital periods with dt = T/100. Record and save to results/baseline_benchmarks.json: (1) relative energy error over time, (2) wall-clock time, (3) position drift. Leapfrog must show oscillating (bounded) energy error while Euler shows secular drift, consistent with literature on symplectic vs non-symplectic methods.

items.description: Implement 4th-order Runge-Kutta (RK4) integrator
items.acceptance_criteria: src/integrators.py extended with an RK4 integrator. At least 4 tests verifying 4th-order convergence: halving dt must reduce single-step error by factor ~16. All existing tests still pass.

items.description: Implement adaptive time-stepping for close encounters
items.acceptance_criteria: src/integrators.py includes an adaptive leapfrog that reduces dt when any pair of bodies is within a threshold distance. Tests demonstrate that a highly eccentric (e=0.9) orbit maintains |dE/E0| < 1e-3 over 50 periods, while fixed-step leapfrog with the same average dt exceeds this threshold.

items.description: Analyze softening parameter effects on energy conservation and force accuracy
items.acceptance_criteria: Run the two-body circular orbit with softening epsilon in {0, 0.001, 0.01, 0.1, 1.0}. Save results to results/softening_analysis.json documenting: (1) steady-state energy error, (2) force error vs analytic at r=1, (3) simulation stability (crash or no crash at epsilon=0). Write a paragraph in results/softening_analysis.md interpreting results and citing relevant literature from sources.bib.

items.description: Implement simple matplotlib visualization of orbits and energy
items.acceptance_criteria: src/visualize.py produces two plots: (1) 2D orbit trajectories of all bodies, (2) relative energy error vs time. Plots saved as PNG to figures/. At least one test verifying plot files are created without errors.

items.description: Implement a 3-body figure-eight choreography as a stress test
items.acceptance_criteria: Set up the Moore (1993) figure-eight three-body initial conditions. Run with leapfrog for 10 periods. The three bodies must return to within 1% of their starting positions. Save trajectory plot to figures/figure_eight.png. Cite the relevant choreography paper in sources.bib.

items.description: Systematic integrator comparison across all methods
items.acceptance_criteria: Run Euler, leapfrog, adaptive leapfrog, and RK4 on: (a) circular orbit, (b) eccentric orbit e=0.5, (c) figure-eight. For each, record energy error, positional accuracy, and wall-clock time. Save structured results to results/integrator_comparison.json with at least 12 data points (4 methods x 3 scenarios).

items.description: Convergence order verification for all integrators
items.acceptance_criteria: For each integrator, run the circular Kepler orbit with dt in {T/50, T/100, T/200, T/400, T/800}. Plot log(error) vs log(dt) and fit the slope. Verify: Euler ~1st order, leapfrog ~2nd order, RK4 ~4th order. Save plot to figures/convergence_orders.png and slopes to results/convergence_orders.json.

items.description: Long-term stability test over 10,000 orbital periods
items.acceptance_criteria: Run leapfrog and RK4 on the circular orbit for 10,000 periods with dt=T/200. Record energy error at each period. Leapfrog energy error must remain bounded (no secular growth). RK4 may show slow drift. Save time-series to results/long_term_stability.json and plot to figures/long_term_stability.png. Compare findings against Dehnen & Read (2011) predictions.

items.description: Scaling test: N-body random cluster with N = 3, 10, 50, 100
items.acceptance_criteria: Generate random N-body initial conditions (virial equilibrium not required; just random positions/velocities in a unit box). Run leapfrog for 100 steps at each N. Record wall-clock time and verify O(N^2) scaling. Save results to results/scaling_test.json and plot to figures/scaling_test.png.

items.description: Compare results against prior work and known analytic solutions
items.acceptance_criteria: Write results/comparison_with_literature.md comparing: (1) our convergence orders against textbook values, (2) our leapfrog energy conservation against Hernquist & Springel (reported in Dehnen & Read 2011), (3) our figure-eight stability against Chenciner & Montgomery (2000). At least 5 citations from sources.bib referenced in the comparison.

items.description: Generate publication-quality figures for all experiments
items.acceptance_criteria: All figures in figures/ re-rendered with consistent style: labeled axes, legends, appropriate font sizes, both PNG and PDF formats. At least 5 distinct figures covering: orbits, energy conservation, convergence, long-term stability, and scaling.

items.description: Write comprehensive research report
items.acceptance_criteria: results/research_report.md exists with sections: Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, References. At least 2000 words. All experimental findings from Phase 4 incorporated. At least 8 citations from sources.bib. Discusses trade-offs between symplectic and non-symplectic integrators for gravitational N-body simulation.

items.description: Create reproducibility package
items.acceptance_criteria: Repo root contains: (1) requirements.txt listing all Python dependencies, (2) Makefile or run.sh that reproduces all experiments and figures from scratch, (3) README.md updated with project description, setup instructions, and usage examples. Running the reproduction script must complete without errors.

items.description: Structured comparison table of all integrator methods
items.acceptance_criteria: results/comparison_table.md contains a markdown table with columns: Method, Order, Symplectic?, Energy Error (circular), Energy Error (eccentric), Wall-clock (N=100), and Recommended Use Case. All 4 integrators represented with data from Phase 4 experiments.

items.description: Final validation checklist and self-assessment
items.acceptance_criteria: results/validation_checklist.md confirms: (1) all tests pass, (2) all figures generated, (3) all results JSON files present and valid, (4) sources.bib has >= 10 entries, (5) research report >= 2000 words, (6) reproduction script runs end-to-end, (7) energy conservation meets stated thresholds for at least the leapfrog integrator.
